entry.title: Time Series
entry.summary: Graphics Title, axes titling [plot command] + ggtitle("title") + xlab("x axis title") + ylab("y axis title")   Time plots Data plotted against time - straightforward. Seasonal plots Data plotted against seasons in which data was observed . "Seasons" means any recurring period of time in the calendar (seasons, months, hours, etc.). ggseasonplot(DATA, year.labels=TRUE, year.labels.left=TRUE) Polar seasonal plot shows data in polar coordinates - just another way of looking at the data. ggseasonplot(DATA, polar=TRUE)   Seasonal subseries plots Data for each season is consolidated into separate mini time plots. This is basically a "sort by season" visualization - instead of sorting by the time recorded in the data, you sort by season, thus placing the seasons in the x-axis. The blue line indicates the mean for each season. ggsubseriesplot(DATA)   Scatterplots It can be useful to explore relationships between time series. The graph below shows the relationship between temperature and electricity demand. When the weather gets hot, demand for electricity increases because of air-conditioning; likewise, cold weather increases demand because of heating. Correlation The correlation coefficient tells the strength of the linear relationship between two variables. It is given by The correlation strength is given by the absolute value of the correlation coefficient - the closer the strength is to 1, the stronger it is. Negative values imply negative correlation, while positive values imply positive correlation.   Lagplots Lagplots plot lagged values; more specifically, is plotted against for different values of . In the example below, the value of k is shown at the top of each subplot. The colors indicate the quarter of the variable on the vertical axis. Lag 1 compares variables that differ by one quarter (variable compared with variable directly preceding it). Notice that lags 4 and 8 show a strong positive correlation. The data is divided into the four quarters of the year, so this is to be expected because similar results should result for similar times in the year (e.g. lag 4 compares 4th quarter results with the previous year's 4th quarter results.).   Autocorrelation coefficient The autocorrelation coefficient measures the linear relationship between lagged values of a time series; for varying values of k, it is defined as Autocorrelation coefficients for lag lengths from 1 to lag.max can be computed with acf(data, lag.max=maximum lag value). Shown below is a correlogram, which shows autocorrelation values for varying lag lengths. The dashed blue lines mark , which indicate statistical significance. Trend and seasonality in ACF plots The autocorrelation values for data with a trend are usually large and positive because observations that occur close to each other are also similar in size. Therefore, as lag lengths get larger and larger, the autocorrelation values decrease. Additionally, autocorrelation values for data with strong seasonality are larger on the multiples of seasonal lag (e.g. multiples of 4 if there are 4 seasons). Below shows data with a trend and strong seasonality. The correlogram shows higher autocorrelation for seasonal lag multiples and a slow decrease over time. White noise A white noise time series is a time series that shows no autocorrelation. Generally, 95% of the autocorrelation values of a white noise time series lie within . On the hand, if more than 5% of the autocorrelation values are outside the dashed blue lines, then the time series is probably not white noise. Exercises Problem 7 The arrivals data set comprises quarterly international arrivals to Australia from Japan, New Zealand, UK, and US. Compare the differences between the arrivals from these four countries. Combined time plot NZ and US show a steady increase in the number of trips to Australia, while the remaining two decrease after a period of steady increase. Seasonality and trend is clear for all four countries. Generally, NZ travels to Australia the most out of the four countries. Japan surged from the lowest to the greatest, topping out at 1995 before declining back to the lowest country. Japan and Australia have had warm relations since the 1970s, with Australia supplying a large amount of Japan's food and raw materials. However the steady decline continuing to the present day requires further research. Australia is also a British Commonwealth Nation, but this doesn't say much about the UK's arrival trends.

entry.title: Measure Theory, Ergodicity, and Entropy
entry.content:
Sugary lattes

What do baristas and bakers have in common? They both mix things. Baristas mix water or milk with espressos, and bakers (sometimes) mix cinnamon or chocolate chips into dough.

What is size?

Measure theory defines the concept of size. Length, area, volume, and even counting are all used to measure the "size" of an object, so mathematicians refer to these measurement concepts as measures. Unfortunately the overarching commonalities between these measures, or the essence of a measure, is difficult to define rigorously. For our purposes, going into the nitty-gritty of what makes a measure isn't important, but here are the three defining qualities of a measure.

  1. The measure of nothing (null-ness, emptiness, etc.) is 0.
  2. The measure of an object is always greater than or equal to 0.
  3. The measure of a whole is equal to the sum of its nonoverlapping parts' measures.
To give an example, counting satisfies all the measure conditions. A sock drawer always contains no socks or a positive number of socks, unless counting negative numbers of things is possible - if you can, shoot me a message because I like magic. If not, counting surely satisfies the first and second qualities. For the last quality, notice the obvious fact that two separate sock drawers, each with 10 socks, hold a total of 20 socks.

As with all things math or philosophy related, we have to define the concept of zero/nothingness. Intuitively, something with zero length is nothing at all; it has no dimension and doesn't exist. Measure theory says different. Take a line segment that extends from 0 to 1, which has a length/measure of 1. Removing 0 and 1 from this line doesn't change the line's length at all, so the points 0 and 1 must both have measures of 0. This means that in the measure theoretical sense, it's possible for non-nothing objects to have a measure of zero - a "zero-ness", if you will.

This loose definition of zero means that measure theory can provide a rigorous basis for our intuitions concerning "almost-ness". Statements that make intuitive sense, such as "almost every pug has a squiggly tail" or "almost everyone has hair", now have a rigorous basis. To say that a property holds for almost everything means that the measure of those things that don't satisfy the property is zero. For example, if one tiny drop of green food coloring is dropped into a glass of water, then since the measure of the tiny green drop is practically 0, almost every particle in the glass is water.

Ergodic farms

A process is ergodic if it mixes the particles of a system "well". Concretely speaking, given any significant sub-region of a system, an ergodic process mixes the system's particles in such a way that they travel in and out of the selected region. To picture this, imagine cows in a fenced cow field. An ergodic farm has no patches of grass that contain the same cows for all eternity; in contrast, an non-ergodic farm has at least one patch where the same cows dwell forever. In the image below, the red indicates individual cow movement, and the green marks an arbitrary patch of grass in the ergodic case and a specific patch in the other.

See how an ergodic process moves the cows around so that no cows stay in the same region forever? Likewise, a non-ergodic process has a specific patch where the cows inside it never leave, and the cows outside never enter.

Dartboards and Time Machines

Imagine a dartboard, with a total area of 1, where each region's score is inversely proportional to its area; the bigger the region, the less it's worth. In the weird metaphorical world that we are in, the dartboard regions change every second.

Further Reading

  1. For the more mathematically inclined, see my relatively self-contained exposition on ergodic theory and entropy; it assumes knowledge of Lebesgue integration, and introduces various notions of entropy such as measure-theoretical entropy and the Lyapunov exponent.

  2. Cesar Ernesto Silva's Invitation to Ergodic Theory is a self-contained measure theory/ergodic theory text. This is what I used to study dynamics during the summer - it's awesome.
